div.l: A wist not where sheo was for hit was derk
And feyre ⁊and wel sheo crepeth vn to the clerk
And lith ful still ⁊and wolde haue caught a slep
Wᵗith Inne a while this Iohn the clerk vp lep
And on this good wyf leyde on sore
So mery a fytte had sheo not ful yore
He priketh harde ⁊and depe as he were mad
This Ioly lyf haue this clerkes lad
Till that the thridde cok bi gan to synge
¶ Aleyne wox wery in the dawenynge
For he had swonken al the longe night
And seyde farewell Aleyne my swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger a byde
But euermore where so I go or ryde
I am thyn owne clerk so haue I sele
¶ Now farewel frend go fare wele
But of oo thyng or thou go I wol the telle
When thou wendest homward bi the mylle
Right at the entre of the mylle dore bi hynde
Thou shalt a cake of half a busshell fynde
That was made of thyn owne mele
The whiche I halpe my syre to stele
And gode leman god the saue ⁊and kepe
And wᵗith that word almost sheo bi gan to wepe
¶ Aleyne vp ryseth ⁊and thought or hit dawe
I wol crepen in bi my felawe
And fond the cradell wᵗith his hond a non
Bi god thought he al wrong I haue mys gon
Myn hed is toty of my swynke to night
That maketh me that I go not a right
I wot wel bi the cradell I haue mys go
Here lith the myller ⁊and his wyf also
